values.description:
This adds some very basic functionality including:

1. An Entity class. Review pull request #3 first, which breaks out the Entity portion.

1. A System class. Review pull request #4 first, which breaks out the Entity portion.

1. A simple server, which essentially performs a no-op.

1. A main executable, which runs the server.
values.title: Server

summary.html:
This adds some very basic functionality including:

  1. An Entity class. Review pull request #3 first, which breaks out the Entity portion.

  2. A System class. Review pull request #4 first, which breaks out the Entity portion.

  3. A simple server, which essentially performs a no-op.

  4. A main executable, which runs the server.

values.reason: This has grown beyond the orignial intent of the pull request. I need to break this down into smaller pull requests.

values.description:
This fixes the issues mentioned in [this comment](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/5/server/diff#comment-60435533).

- We require SDFormat version 6 specifically, so configuration will now fail if the machine does not have that version installed
- We get `ign-math4` and `ign-msgs1` transitively through `ign-transport4`
- We should not link against `ign-math5` when we are also linking against libraries that use `ign-math4`
values.title: Simplify and correct the ignition dependencies

summary.raw:
This fixes the issues mentioned in [this comment](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/5/server/diff#comment-60435533).

- We require SDFormat version 6 specifically, so configuration will now fail if the machine does not have that version installed
- We get `ign-math4` and `ign-msgs1` transitively through `ign-transport4`
- We should not link against `ign-math5` when we are also linking against libraries that use `ign-math4`
summary.html:
This fixes the issues mentioned in this comment.

  • We require SDFormat version 6 specifically, so configuration will now fail if the machine does not have that version installed
  • We get ign-math4 and ign-msgs1 transitively through ign-transport4
  • We should not link against ign-math5 when we are also linking against libraries that use ign-math4

values.description:
The goal is for it to compile and load the plugins, there are still problems being solved with the 3D scene and the time panel is just a couple of buttons I threw there. This will all change!

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1895266187-gzquick.png)
---

Added the `TmpIface` class to put some ign-transport services and topics which interact with the GUI. I created this class because it's not clear to me yet where these services should go in the backend.

---

This PR requires [this ign-gui PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/134/gz11-menu-configuration/diff#chg-examples/standalone/custom_drawer/custom_drawer.cc).

The drawer menu now provides some options which call backend services, and others which perform default ign-gui actions:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2535240202-customdrawer.png)
values.title: QtQuick support and temporary transport interface

The goal is for it to compile and load the plugins, there are still problems being solved with the 3D scene and the time panel is just a couple of buttons I threw there. This will all change!

Added the TmpIface class to put some ign-transport services and topics which interact with the GUI. I created this class because it's not clear to me yet where these services should go in the backend.

This PR requires this ign-gui PR.

The drawer menu now provides some options which call backend services, and others which perform default ign-gui actions:

values.description:
This adds a component manager that handles storage of components. The goal of the component manager is to store components of the same type in adjacent memory.

A server has also been added. The server is pretty minimal right now. It can run, but systems are not currently supported.
values.title: Server update

values.description:
This is a fairly large PR, but there are a lot of connect pieces. Key improvements:

‌

1. Systems are now available. An example Physics system is in place. This system is just an example, and will be removed/updated when we integrate with ign-physics.
2. PoseComponent has been added. This is also  just a simple example. In reality we will not have such low-level components.
3. It is possible for a system to inform the server about the types of entities the system requires. This happens through an EntityQuery.
4. The ComponentManager has been expanded and renamed EntityComponentManager. This new class manages Component, Entities, and what components belong to what entity.

There are a lot of `todos` in the code indicating what will be worked on in the near future.

Right now the only major output difference can be seen with:

`ign-gazebo -s -f test/worlds/shapes.sdf`

The above should output the initial pose values of each model.
values.title: Systems

summary.raw:
This is a fairly large PR, but there are a lot of connect pieces. Key improvements:

‌

1. Systems are now available. An example Physics system is in place. This system is just an example, and will be removed/updated when we integrate with ign-physics.
2. PoseComponent has been added. This is also  just a simple example. In reality we will not have such low-level components.
3. It is possible for a system to inform the server about the types of entities the system requires. This happens through an EntityQuery.
4. The ComponentManager has been expanded and renamed EntityComponentManager. This new class manages Component, Entities, and what components belong to what entity.

There are a lot of `todos` in the code indicating what will be worked on in the near future.

Right now the only major output difference can be seen with:

`ign-gazebo -s -f test/worlds/shapes.sdf`

The above should output the initial pose values of each model.
summary.html:
This is a fairly large PR, but there are a lot of connect pieces. Key improvements:

‌

  1. Systems are now available. An example Physics system is in place. This system is just an example, and will be removed/updated when we integrate with ign-physics.
  2. PoseComponent has been added. This is also just a simple example. In reality we will not have such low-level components.
  3. It is possible for a system to inform the server about the types of entities the system requires. This happens through an EntityQuery.
  4. The ComponentManager has been expanded and renamed EntityComponentManager. This new class manages Component, Entities, and what components belong to what entity.

There are a lot of todos in the code indicating what will be worked on in the near future.

Right now the only major output difference can be seen with:

ign-gazebo -s -f test/worlds/shapes.sdf

The above should output the initial pose values of each model.

values.description:
This PR provides a world statistics component along with proper sim time, real time, and real-time factor computation. Also added \`mutable\` accessors to EntityComponentManager that provide non-const component access.

A couple bugs have been fixed along the way:

1. Remove the use of `std::any`, which was causing an extra copy.
2. Use `noexcept` to prevent an extra copy.

## A simple test

**Terminal 1**

./bin/ign-gazebo -f ../test/worlds/shapes.sdf

**Terminal 2**

ign-topic -e -t /world/default/stats
values.title: World stats system

values.description:
This will add support for running multiple worlds on a single server. Each world is managed by a `SimulationRunner`. The reason to do this are:

1. Support development and testing of distributed simulation.
2. Add multiple world support from the start, otherwise we will develop ourselves into a corner that would prevent or make it very difficult to use multiple worlds.
3. Support tasks like parameter search, pause one world then load and run another while maintaining state of the first.
4. This could eventually be used to create new models in a clean world \(model editor\), and then insert the model into a different world.

TODO list:

1. Support <physics> SDF parameters so that I can load worlds with different time steps.

    1. Implemented: [85c2e6b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/85c2e6b5f2020d5cef3585c39b7a6b49532809c1?at=world_stats_system)
    
2. Code cleanup - there are a few commented out functions. Done

‌

Requires: [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/456/gz11-physics-dom/diff](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/456/gz11-physics-dom/diff)
values.title: Simulation runner

summary.raw:
This will add support for running multiple worlds on a single server. Each world is managed by a `SimulationRunner`. The reason to do this are:

1. Support development and testing of distributed simulation.
2. Add multiple world support from the start, otherwise we will develop ourselves into a corner that would prevent or make it very difficult to use multiple worlds.
3. Support tasks like parameter search, pause one world then load and run another while maintaining state of the first.
4. This could eventually be used to create new models in a clean world \(model editor\), and then insert the model into a different world.

TODO list:

1. Support <physics> SDF parameters so that I can load worlds with different time steps.

    1. Implemented: [85c2e6b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/85c2e6b5f2020d5cef3585c39b7a6b49532809c1?at=world_stats_system)
    
2. Code cleanup - there are a few commented out functions. Done

‌

summary.html:
This will add support for running multiple worlds on a single server. Each world is managed by a SimulationRunner. The reason to do this are:

  1. Support development and testing of distributed simulation.
  2. Add multiple world support from the start, otherwise we will develop ourselves into a corner that would prevent or make it very difficult to use multiple worlds.
  3. Support tasks like parameter search, pause one world then load and run another while maintaining state of the first.
  4. This could eventually be used to create new models in a clean world (model editor), and then insert the model into a different world.

TODO list:

  1. Support <physics> SDF parameters so that I can load worlds with different time steps.

    1. Implemented: 85c2e6b

  2. Code cleanup - there are a few commented out functions. Done

‌

Requires: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/456/gz11-physics-dom/diff

values.description:
@chapulina  @carromj Here is a project for you to chew on. I added some text in EntityComponentManager that describes the general direction. Also check out the provided link, which was the inspiration for this change.

I image that the existing “EntityQuery/Registrar” and InitSystems code can all go away. 

Get ready for template magic!!!

I’m officially handing this over to you both. Hit me up with question by the end of the day tomorrow.

values.description:
Before I start adding a bunch of components:

* Move components to a separate dir and namespace
* Remove `Component` from the class names
* Removed `Name()` function from components, only left the one in `World` because it's used and currently represents the world name, not the component name like it was for the others.
values.title: Move components to a dir and namespace

values.title: Move systems to a dir and namespace

values.description:
* Reorganize systems into plugins that can be loaded at runtime.

    * Adds a SystemPluginManager for finding and loading plugins.
    * Adds a NullSystem plugin to verify multiple plugins can be loaded.
    
* Continued work on systems, focused on loading mechanism.

    * SystemPluginManger -> SystemManager
    * Make System an interface.
    * Add configuration parsing similar to ign-gui
    * Add a test system and configuration
    
* Load systems by name, in the case that multiple are in the same library.
* Codecheck.
* Rework of system\_plugins with new structure taken into account.
values.title: System plugins

summary.raw:
* Reorganize systems into plugins that can be loaded at runtime.

    * Adds a SystemPluginManager for finding and loading plugins.
    * Adds a NullSystem plugin to verify multiple plugins can be loaded.
    
* Continued work on systems, focused on loading mechanism.

    * SystemPluginManger -> SystemManager
    * Make System an interface.
    * Add configuration parsing similar to ign-gui
    * Add a test system and configuration
    
* Load systems by name, in the case that multiple are in the same library.
* Codecheck.
* Rework of system\_plugins with new structure taken into account.
summary.html:
• Reorganize systems into plugins that can be loaded at runtime.

    • Adds a SystemPluginManager for finding and loading plugins.
    • Adds a NullSystem plugin to verify multiple plugins can be loaded.

  • Continued work on systems, focused on loading mechanism.

    • SystemPluginManger -> SystemManager
    • Make System an interface.
    • Add configuration parsing similar to ign-gui
    • Add a test system and configuration

  • Load systems by name, in the case that multiple are in the same library.

  • Codecheck.
  • Rework of system_plugins with new structure taken into account.

values.description:
| Entity | Components |
| -------- | ------------------ |
| World | Name, World | 
| Model | Pose, Name, ParentEntity, Model	 | 
| Link | Pose, Name, ParentEntity, Link | 
| Collision | Pose, Name, ParentEntity, Collision | 
| Visual | Pose, Name, ParentEntity, Visual | 

I recommend taking a look at `SimulationRunner_TEST`.

TODOs:

* Store `sdf::Collision` into `ignition::gazebo::components::Collision`
* Sort out the `Each` function because it's currently returning all entities.
values.title: New components: Model, Link, Collision, Visual, Name, ParentEntity

values.description:
Move time handling to `SimulationRunner`, which means:

* Remove `WorldStatistics` component and system
* `World` component now is just an identifier like `components::Model` or `components::Link`
* Systems receive `UpdateInfo` at the update callback, which contains info about time and iterations.
* World statistics are published by `SimulationRunner`
* World controls service is provided by `SimulationRunner`

---

# Concepts

Some important ideas, which are open to discussion, are:

* ECS systems are updated even while paused. This is important for interacting with the GUI.
* While paused, sim iterations and sim time don't increase.
* While paused, the step size (`dt`) passed to each system is zero. Right now, it is up to the system to check that and behave accordingly.
* The step size is 10ms by default (placeholder) and can be overridden from the SDF (`<max_step_size>`).
* The ECS period is calculated based on the step size and the desired RTF, see calculation comments on `SimulationRunner.cc`; it can be overridden from the command line with `-z`

The image below summarizes some of these ideas:

![ECSRTF.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1055788081-ECSRTF.png)

---

# Demo

`ign-gazebo -f test/worlds/shapes.sdf  -v 4 -z 3`

![playpause_pot.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/4020974896-playpause_pot.gif)

---

---

# Future work

* Even if I try to run faster than real time, with `-z 10000` for example, the maximum RTF I get is less than 160%. It would be good to port `gazebo_experimental`'s [DiagnosticsManager](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_experimental/src/d828f7845f99ecb5da097f1c89b32da809bd9fd9/include/gazebo/util/DiagnosticsManager.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) here to see what's going on
* Add command line option to start paused
* `--iterations` should set sim iterations, not ECS (usually only relevant if you start paused)
values.title: Refactor stats and support play / pause / step

summary.raw:
Move time handling to `SimulationRunner`, which means:

* Remove `WorldStatistics` component and system
* `World` component now is just an identifier like `components::Model` or `components::Link`
* Systems receive `UpdateInfo` at the update callback, which contains info about time and iterations.
* World statistics are published by `SimulationRunner`
* World controls service is provided by `SimulationRunner`

---

# Concepts

Some important ideas, which are open to discussion, are:

* ECS systems are updated even while paused. This is important for interacting with the GUI.
* While paused, sim iterations and sim time don't increase.
* While paused, the step size (`dt`) passed to each system is zero. Right now, it is up to the system to check that and behave accordingly.
* The step size is 10ms by default (placeholder) and can be overridden from the SDF (`<max_step_size>`).
* The ECS period is calculated based on the step size and the desired RTF, see calculation comments on `SimulationRunner.cc`; it can be overridden from the command line with `-z`

The image below summarizes some of these ideas:

![ECSRTF.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1055788081-ECSRTF.png)

# Future work

* Even if I try to run faster than real time, with `-z 10000` for example, the maximum RTF I get is less than 160%. It would be good to port `gazebo_experimental`'s [DiagnosticsManager](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_experimental/src/d828f7845f99ecb5da097f1c89b32da809bd9fd9/include/gazebo/util/DiagnosticsManager.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) here to see what's going on

summary.html:
Move time handling to SimulationRunner, which means:

  • Remove WorldStatistics component and system
  • World component now is just an identifier like components::Model or components::Link
  • Systems receive UpdateInfo at the update callback, which contains info about time and iterations.
  • World statistics are published by SimulationRunner
  • World controls service is provided by SimulationRunner

Concepts

Some important ideas, which are open to discussion, are:

  • ECS systems are updated even while paused. This is important for interacting with the GUI.
  • While paused, sim iterations and sim time don't increase.
  • While paused, the step size (dt) passed to each system is zero. Right now, it is up to the system to check that and behave accordingly.
  • The step size is 10ms by default (placeholder) and can be overridden from the SDF (<max_step_size>).
  • The ECS period is calculated based on the step size and the desired RTF, see calculation comments on SimulationRunner.cc; it can be overridden from the command line with -z

The image below summarizes some of these ideas:

Demo

ign-gazebo -f test/worlds/shapes.sdf -v 4 -z 3

Future work

  • Even if I try to run faster than real time, with -z 10000 for example, the maximum RTF I get is less than 160%. It would be good to port gazebo_experimental's DiagnosticsManager here to see what's going on
  • Add command line option to start paused
  • --iterations should set sim iterations, not ECS (usually only relevant if you start paused)

values.description:
First draft of the rendering system. It's still a work in progress, I'm opening the PR for visibility and to get feedback from @iche033.

---

## Functionality

* Initialize render engine and scene on constructor
* On update, create a `rendering::Visual` for every entity that has a pose and a parent. 
    * This includes "invisible" visuals like models and links, so we can set their poses and affect eventual visible children.
    * If there's no visual for the parent, we assume the parent is the world and attach it to the scene root
* Create geometry and material from SDF objects
* At subsequent updates, update visual pose

---

## Issues

The scene is being initialized properly, because we can see the background color is the one we chose.

But no visuals are showing up. Neither the box created on the constructor nor the shapes created on the update callback. I suspect the render window is never being repainted. @iche033, do you think this is indeed the problem, or is there something wrong in the code?

---

## Usage

Load `shapes.world` as follows:

    ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../test/worlds/shapes.sdf
values.title: [WIP] Rendering system

---

## Functionality

* Initialize render engine and scene on constructor

But no visuals are showing up. Neither the box created on the constructor nor the shapes created on the update callback. I suspect the render window is never being repainted. @iche033, do you think this is indeed the problem, or is there something wrong in the code?

summary.html:
First draft of the rendering system. It's still a work in progress, I'm opening the PR for visibility and to get feedback from @iche033.

Functionality

  • Initialize render engine and scene on constructor
  • On update, create a rendering::Visual for every entity that has a pose and a parent.
    • This includes "invisible" visuals like models and links, so we can set their poses and affect eventual visible children.
    • If there's no visual for the parent, we assume the parent is the world and attach it to the scene root
  • Create geometry and material from SDF objects
  • At subsequent updates, update visual pose

Issues

The scene is being initialized properly, because we can see the background color is the one we chose.

But no visuals are showing up. Neither the box created on the constructor nor the shapes created on the update callback. I suspect the render window is never being repainted. @iche033, do you think this is indeed the problem, or is there something wrong in the code?

Usage

Load shapes.world as follows:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../test/worlds/shapes.sdf

values.reason: holding off on a rendering system for now

values.description:
Per discussions with @azeey , some modifications of the System API.

This adds three update phases: `PreUpdate` `Update` and `PostUpdate`

In this paradigm, the PreUpdate and Update phases are intended to be able to modify state, while PostUpdate should be read only.  It is also intended that only Physics will implement the `Update` method.
values.title: [wip] System API

summary.raw:
Per discussions with @azeey , some modifications of the System API.

This adds three update phases: `PreUpdate` `Update` and `PostUpdate`

In this paradigm, the PreUpdate and Update phases are intended to be able to modify state, while PostUpdate should be read only.  It is also intended that only Physics will implement the `Update` method.
summary.html:
Per discussions with @azeey , some modifications of the System API.

This adds three update phases: PreUpdate Update and PostUpdate

In this paradigm, the PreUpdate and Update phases are intended to be able to modify state, while PostUpdate should be read only. It is also intended that only Physics will implement the Update method.

values.description:
Add a system which publishes `ignition::msgs::Scene` messages populated with entities and components. These messages will be consumed by an ign-gui plugin which will populate a rendering scene.

This is part of a temporary alternative to pull request #39. The next PR will add the GUI plugin.

---

## UPDATED

Try it out

1. Load a world:

    `ign-gazebo -v 3 -f ../test/worlds/multiple_worlds.sdf -s`

2. Check the published topics

    `ign topic -l`

        /world/world_one/pose/info
        /world/world_one/stats
        /world/world_three/pose/info
        /world/world_three/stats
        /world/world_two/stats

3. Check the advertised services:

        /world/world_one/control
        /world/world_one/scene/graph
        /world/world_one/scene/info
        /world/world_three/control
        /world/world_three/scene/graph
        /world/world_three/scene/info
        /world/world_two/control

3. Echo pose messages

    `ign topic -e -t /world/world_three/pose/info`

4. Due to [this ign-transport issue](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/issues/97/call-one-way-requester-responder-from), we can't use the `ign service` command line to test the scene services. So an example program was added:

    1. Build the example

            cd examples/standalone/scene_requester
            mkdir build
            cd build
            cmake ..
            make -j8

    1. Request scene info:

            ./scene_requester /world/world_one/scene/info info

    1. Request scene graph:

            ./scene_requester /world/world_one/scene/graph graph

        > Tip: paste the graph output here: http://www.webgraphviz.com/
values.title: New system: Scene broadcaster

This is part of a temporary alternative to pull request #39. The next PR will add the GUI plugin.

UPDATED

Try it out

  5. Due to this ign-transport issue, we can't use the ign service command line to test the scene services. So an example program was added:

values.description:
This pull request integrates ign-physics with ign-gazebo and provides basic capabilities for adding objects from ECS into the physics engine and updating their state at each simulation step.

A few notes:

* ~~Currently, there is ambiguity in the frame semantics of Pose components. When entities are created from SDF, the Pose component contains the pose of the entity relative to its parent. However, after the physics update, this Pose component holds the absolute pose of the entity. We might need to add a RelativePose component to implement frame semantics.~~
* A default physics time step of 1 ms is assumed.
* ~~One of the tests checks whether collisions are working and depends on a fix to ign-physics \(see~~ [~~this~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/32/feature-system-part-7-features-for/diff?w=1#comment-75815369)~~\) before it passes. My proposed fix is:~~ [~~PR ign-physics#35~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/35)
* ~~There is initial work on parsing joints, but I need to add more components to capture the various properties of joints. I haven’t written any code to add joints to the physics engine.~~
* Since this system depends on ign-physics, I’ve pulled it into its own library
* We currently don’t have a way to pass config parameters to systems so the path to the specific ign-physics plugin is passed by via a cmake define while it’s class name is hardcoded.

‌

## Update:

* I have removed joint parsing and the components associated with it. It will be it’s own pull request
* This pull request still depends on an open[ ign-physics pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/32/)
values.title: Basic Physics System

summary.raw:
This pull request integrates ign-physics with ign-gazebo and provides basic capabilities for adding objects from ECS into the physics engine and updating their state at each simulation step.

A few notes:

* ~~Currently, there is ambiguity in the frame semantics of Pose components. When entities are created from SDF, the Pose component contains the pose of the entity relative to its parent. However, after the physics update, this Pose component holds the absolute pose of the entity. We might need to add a RelativePose component to implement frame semantics.~~
* A default physics time step of 1 ms is assumed.
* ~~One of the tests checks whether collisions are working and depends on a fix to ign-physics \(see~~ [~~this~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/32/feature-system-part-7-features-for/diff?w=1#comment-75815369)~~\) before it passes. My proposed fix is:~~ [~~PR ign-physics#35~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/35)
* ~~There is initial work on parsing joints, but I need to add more components to capture the various properties of joints. I haven’t written any code to add joints to the physics engine.~~
* Since this system depends on ign-physics, I’ve pulled it into its own library
* We currently don’t have a way to pass config parameters to systems so the path to the specific ign-physics plugin is passed by via a cmake define while it’s class name is hardcoded.

‌

## Update:

* I have removed joint parsing and the components associated with it. It will be it’s own pull request
* This pull request still depends on an open[ ign-physics pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/32/)
summary.html:
This pull request integrates ign-physics with ign-gazebo and provides basic capabilities for adding objects from ECS into the physics engine and updating their state at each simulation step.

A few notes:

  • Currently, there is ambiguity in the frame semantics of Pose components. When entities are created from SDF, the Pose component contains the pose of the entity relative to its parent. However, after the physics update, this Pose component holds the absolute pose of the entity. We might need to add a RelativePose component to implement frame semantics.
  • A default physics time step of 1 ms is assumed.
  • One of the tests checks whether collisions are working and depends on a fix to ign-physics (see this) before it passes. My proposed fix is: PR ign-physics#35
  • There is initial work on parsing joints, but I need to add more components to capture the various properties of joints. I haven’t written any code to add joints to the physics engine.
  • Since this system depends on ign-physics, I’ve pulled it into its own library
  • We currently don’t have a way to pass config parameters to systems so the path to the specific ign-physics plugin is passed by via a cmake define while it’s class name is hardcoded.

‌

Update:

  • I have removed joint parsing and the components associated with it. It will be it’s own pull request
  • This pull request still depends on an open ign-physics pull request

values.description:
Add a `<service>`element to gui.config that will be used by ign-gui Scene3D plugin to get scene data

Also updated shapes.sdf sphere radius to a smaller value for testing the rendered scene.

Example of rendering the \`shapes.sdf\` world in Scene3D:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/409319621-ign-gui-scene3d-shapes.png)
‌

for testing, in ign-gazebo directory, run:

    ign-gazebo -v 3 -f test/worlds/shapes.sdf

Requires this [ign-gui PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/156/add-scene-requestor-class-for-populating/diff)

values.description:
Create a tutorial on how to create system plugins, I assumed this would be useful as more people on the team start to develop systems.

It also removes ign-gazebo’s dependence on ign-gazebo-gui \(which is only used as part of the main executable at the moment\).
values.title: Add tutorial for implementing a system plugin.

summary.raw:
Create a tutorial on how to create system plugins, I assumed this would be useful as more people on the team start to develop systems.

It also removes ign-gazebo’s dependence on ign-gazebo-gui \(which is only used as part of the main executable at the moment\).
summary.html:
Create a tutorial on how to create system plugins, I assumed this would be useful as more people on the team start to develop systems.

It also removes ign-gazebo’s dependence on ign-gazebo-gui (which is only used as part of the main executable at the moment).

values.description:
This puts the `ign_find_package(ign-physics ...)` call into the root CMakeLists.txt so that configuration quits gracefully if `ign-physics` cannot be found. As it currently is, cmake will spew a lot of confusing noise if `ign-physics` is unavailable.

Right now it's set as `REQUIRED`, but it could easily be made optional by putting the physics system source code into its own component directory, if that’s something we ever want to do.
values.title: Find ign-physics from the root CMakeLists.txt

summary.raw:
This puts the `ign_find_package(ign-physics ...)` call into the root CMakeLists.txt so that configuration quits gracefully if `ign-physics` cannot be found. As it currently is, cmake will spew a lot of confusing noise if `ign-physics` is unavailable.

Right now it's set as `REQUIRED`, but it could easily be made optional by putting the physics system source code into its own component directory, if that’s something we ever want to do.
summary.html:
This puts the ign_find_package(ign-physics ...) call into the root CMakeLists.txt so that configuration quits gracefully if ign-physics cannot be found. As it currently is, cmake will spew a lot of confusing noise if ign-physics is unavailable.

Right now it's set as REQUIRED, but it could easily be made optional by putting the physics system source code into its own component directory, if that’s something we ever want to do.
